item.title: Linear Methods
item.description: Solving Classification Problems with Linear Models One simple idea behind classification is to calculate the posterior probability of each class given the variables. Suppose a dataset have features $F_\alpha$ where $\alpha = 1, 2, \cdots, K$, with corresponding class labels $G_\alpha$. The dataset that provides $N$ datapoints with each deoted as $X_i$. The posterior of the classification is $P(G = G_\alpha \vert X = X_i)$. A naive idea is to classify the data into two classes $m$ and $n$ using the boundary of a linear model
